revision.text:
{{Use Irish English|date=October 2018}} {{short description|Irish stick-and-ball team sport played by women }} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox sport | image = Camogie.jpg | imagesize = 300px | caption = A junior camogie match being played in [[Croke Park]], Dublin | union = [[Camogie Association]] | nickname = | first = Ireland | first team = 1904 | registered = Over 100,000 | clubs = 536 | contact = [[Contact sports|Contact]] | team = 15 players per side,
substitutes are permitted | mgender = There is no mixed gender/sex version of Camogie. [[Hurling]] is the male counterpart of Camogie | ball = [[Sliotar]] (ball)
Hurley/camán (stick)
Helmet
Shin guards }} '''Camogie''' ({{IPAc-en|k|ɑː|m|ɔː|g|iː}}; {{lang-ga|camógaíocht}}) is an Irish stick-and-ball team sport played by women. Camogie is played by 100,000 women in [[Ireland]] and worldwide, largely among Irish communities.{{cite book | last = Moran | first = Mary | authorlink = Mary Moran (camogie) | title = A Game of Our Own: The History of Camogie | publisher = Cumann Camógaíochta | year = 2011 | location = Dublin, Ireland | pages = 460}}{{cite book | last = Arlott | first = John | title = Oxford Companion to Sports and Games | publisher = Flamingo | year = 1977 | location = London, England | pages = 1024 }} A variant of the game of [[hurling]] (which is played by men only) adapted to suit women, it is organised by the Dublin-based [[Camogie Association]] or [[Camogie Association|An Cumann Camógaíochta]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.camogie.ie/about-camogie.asp|title=The Camogie Association : About Camogie|last=Vuepoint.ie|website=Camogie.ie|language=en|access-date=2017-05-05}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.gaa.ie/my-gaa/getting-involved/camogie|title=GAA.ie|website=Gaa.ie|language=en|access-date=2017-05-05}} [[UNESCO]] lists Camogie as an element of [[Intangible cultural heritage|Intangible Cultural Heritage]].{{Cite web|url=https://ich.unesco.org/en/RL/hurling-01263|title=Hurling - intangible heritage - Culture Sector - UNESCO|website=ich.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-29}} ==The game== [[File:Scoring in Gaelic games - H shaped posts.png|thumb|Goalposts and scoring system used in camogie]] The game consists of two thirty-minute halves. There is a half-time interval of 10 minutes. In event of extra time, halves must consist of 10 minutes each. Each team has 15 players on the field. Within the 15 players the team must consist of one goalkeeper, three full back players, three half back players, two centre-field players, three half forward players and three full forward players. There is a minimum requirement of 12 players on the pitch at all times.{{cite web |url=http://www.camogie.ie/files/Administration+Section/Playing+Rules+2014.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2018-01-15 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116004430/http://www.camogie.ie/files/Administration+Section/Playing+Rules+2014.pdf |archivedate=16 January 2018 |df=dmy-all }} ===Field=== The field is not of a fixed size, but must be between 130m long by 80m wide, and 145m long by 90m wide. ===Goals and scoring=== {{Main|Scoring in Gaelic games}} H-shaped goals are used. A team achieves a score by making the ball go between the posts. If the ball goes over the bar for a "point", the team earns one point. If the ball goes under the bar for a "goal", the team earns three points.{{cite web|url=http://www.camogie.ie/AboutCamogie/CamogiePlayingRules/tabid/59/Default.aspx|title=Rules of Camogie on Camogie.ie website|publisher=|accessdate=15 January 2018}} ==Profile of camogie== The annual [[All-Ireland Senior Camogie Championship|All Ireland Camogie Championship]] has a record attendance of 33,1542007 All Ireland final reports in [http://www.examiner.ie/archives/2007/0910/sport/gaa-chiefs-vow-to-review-ticketing-system-following-glitch-42143.html Irish Examiner], [https://archive.is/20120802093242/http://www.independent.ie/other/wexfords-day-of-glory-1074735.html Irish Independent], [http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2007/0910/1189076008095.html Irish Times] and [http://www.goreyguardian.ie/sport/other-sports/leacy-goals-fire-wexford-to-emotional-victory-1079990.html Gorey Guardian] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120219153020/http://www.goreyguardian.ie/sport/other-sports/leacy-goals-fire-wexford-to-emotional-victory-1079990.html |date=19 February 2012 }} while average attendances in recent years are in the region of 15,000 to 18,000. The final is televised live, with a TV audience of over 300,000 being claimed.{{cite book | last = [[Eoghan Corry|Corry]] | first = Eoghan | title = Illustrated History of the GAA | publisher = Gill & MacMillan | year = 2005 | location = Dublin, Ireland | pages = 250 }} ==Rules== The rules are almost identical to [[hurling]], with a few exceptions.{{cite web|url=http://www.camogie.ie/AboutCamogie/CamogievHurlingRuleDifferences/tabid/60/Default.aspx|title=Rule Differences on Camogie.ie website|publisher=|accessdate=15 January 2018}} *Goalkeepers wear the same colours as outfield players. This is because no special rules apply to the goalkeeper and so there is no need for officials to differentiate between goalkeeper and outfielders. *A camogie player can handpass any score from play ''(handpassing a goal is forbidden in hurling since 1980)''. *Camogie games last 60 minutes, two 30-minute halves ''(senior inter-county hurling games last 70, which is two 35-minute halves)''. Ties are resolved by multiple 2×10-minute [[Sudden death (sport)|sudden death]] extra time periods; in these, the first team to score wins. *Dropping the [[camogie stick]] to handpass the ball is permitted. *A smaller sliotar (ball) is used in camogie – commonly known as a size 4 sliotar – whereas hurlers play with a size 5 sliotar. *If a defending player hits the sliotar wide, a 45-metre puck is awarded to the opposition ''(in hurling, it is a 65-metre puck)''. *After a score, the goalkeeper pucks out from the 13-metre line ''(in hurling, he must puck from the end line)''. *The metal band on the camogie stick must be covered with tape ''(not necessary in hurling)''. *Side-to-side charges are forbidden ''(permitted in hurling)''. *Two points are awarded for a score direct from a sideline cut (since March 2012).{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/hurling/ladies-sticking-with-skirts-as-oflynn-backs-rules-makeover-3066426.html|title=Ladies sticking with skirts as O'Flynn backs rules makeover - Independent.ie|publisher=|accessdate=15 January 2018}} Camogie players must wear [[skirt]]s or [[skort]]s rather than [[shorts]]. ==Foundation== Experimental rules were drawn up in 1903 for a female stick-and-ball game by [[Máire Ní Chinnéide]], [[Seán (Sceilg) Ó Ceallaigh]], [[Tadhg Ó Donnchadha]] and [[Séamus Ó Braonáin]]. The Official Launch of Camogie took place with the first public match between Craobh an Chéitinnigh (Keatings branch of the [[Gaelic League]]) and [[Cúchulainns]] on 17 July at a Feis in Navan. The sport's governing body, the Camogie Association or [[Camogie Association of Ireland|An Cumann Camógaíochta]] was founded in 1905 and re-constituted in 1911, 1923 and 1939. Until June 2010 it was known as Cumann Camógaíochta na nGael. Máire Ní Chinnéide and Cáit Ní Dhonnchadha, two prominent Irish-language enthusiasts and cultural nationalists, were credited with having created the sport, with the assistance of Ní Dhonnchadha's scholarly brother Tadhg Ó Donnchadha, who drew up its rules. Thus, although camogie was founded by women, and independently run (although closely linked to the GAA), there was, from the outset, a small yet powerful male presence within its administrative ranks. It was no surprise that camogie emanated from the Gaelic League, nor that it would be dependent upon the structures and networks provided by that organisation during the initial expansion of the sport. Of all the cultural nationalist organisations for adults that emerged during the fin de siècle, the Gaelic League was the only one to accept female and male members on an equal footing.Ríona Nic Congáil “'Looking on for centuries from the side-line': Gaelic Feminism and the rise of Camogie", Éire-Ireland (Spring / Summer 2013): 168–192.[https://www.academia.edu/3324668/Looking_on_for_centuries_from_the_side-line_Gaelic_Feminism_and_the_rise_of_Camogie Gaelic Feminism and the rise of Camogie] [[File:Camogie Team, Waterford, 17 October 1915.jpg|thumb|A camogie team pictured in Waterford in October 1915]] ==Historic rules== Under [[Séamus Ó Braonáin]]'s original 1903 camogie rules both the match and the field were shorter than their hurling equivalents. Matches were 40 minutes, increased to 50 minutes in 1934, and playing fields 125–130 yards (114-119m) long and 65–70 yards (59-64m) wide. From 1929 until 1979 a second crossbar, a "points bar" was also used, meaning that a point would not be allowed if it travelled over this bar, a somewhat contentious rule through the 75 years it was in use. Teams were regulated at 12 a side, using an elliptical formation, although it was more a "squeezed lemon" formation with the three midfield players grouped more closely together than their counterpart on the half back and half-forward lines. In 1999 camogie moved to the GAA field-size and 15-a-side, adopting the standard GAA butterfly formation. ==Nomenclature== The name was invented by [[Tadhg Ó Donnchadha|Tadhg Ua Donnchadha]] (Tórna) at meetings in 1903 in advance of the first matches in 1904. {{cite book | last = Puirséil | first = Pádraig | title = Scéal na Camógaíochta | publisher = [[Camogie Association of Ireland|Cumann Camógaíochta na nGael]] | year = 1984 | location = Dublin, Ireland | pages = 64 }} Men play using a curved stick called in Irish a ''camán''. Women would use a shorter stick, at one stage described by the diminutive form ''camóg''. The suffix -''aíocht'' (originally "uidheacht") was added to both words to give names for the sports: ''camánaíocht'' (which became ''iománaíocht'') and ''camógaíocht''. When the [[Gaelic Athletic Association]] was founded in 1884 the English-origin name "hurling" was given to the men's game. When an organisation for women was set up in 1904, it was decided to anglicise the Irish name ''camógaíocht'' to ''camogie''. ==Structure== [[Camogie Association|An Cumann Camógaíochta]] has a similar structure to the [[Gaelic Athletic Association]], with an Annual Congress every spring which decides on policy and major issues such as rule changes, and an executive council, the Árd Chómhairle which deals with short-term issues and governance. The game is administered from a headquarters in [[Croke Park]] in Dublin. Each of 28 [[Gaelic Athletic Association county|county board]]s takes control of its own affairs (all of the Irish counties except [[Fermanagh GAA|Fermanagh]], [[Leitrim GAA|Leitrim]] and [[Sligo GAA|Sligo]]), with the number of clubs ranging from 58 in [[Cork GAA|Cork]] to one in [[Leitrim GAA|Leitrim]]. There are four provincial councils and affiliates in [[Asia GAA|Asia]], [[Australia GAA|Australia]], [[Britain GAA|Britain]], [[Europe GAA|Europe]], [[New York GAA|New York]], [[New Zealand GAA|New Zealand]] and [[North American GAA|North America]]. ==Camogie clubs== There are 537 camogie clubs, of which 513 (95.5%) are based on the island of Ireland, 47 in [[Connacht GAA#Camogie|Connacht]] (8.8%), 195 in [[Leinster GAA#Camogie|Leinster]] (36.4%), 160 in [[Munster GAA#Camogie|Munster]] (29.8%), and 110 in [[Ulster GAA#Camogie|Ulster]] (20.5%). {{Div col|colwidth=15em}} * [[Antrim GAA#Camogie|Antrim]] 22 * [[Armagh GAA#Camogie|Armagh]] 18 * [[Carlow GAA#Camogie|Carlow]] 6 * [[Cavan GAA#Camogie|Cavan]] 9 * [[Clare GAA#Camogie|Clare]] 26 * [[Cork GAA#Camogie|Cork]] 58 * [[Derry GAA#Camogie|Derry]] 23 * [[Donegal GAA#Camogie|Donegal]] 3 * [[Down GAA#Camogie|Down]] 21 * [[Dublin GAA#Camogie|Dublin]] 39 * [[Europe GAA#Camogie|Europe]] 4 * [[Fermanagh GAA#Camogie|Fermanagh]] 0 * [[Galway GAA#Camogie|Galway]] 34 * [[Kerry GAA#Camogie|Kerry]] 3 * [[Kildare GAA#Camogie|Kildare]] 19 * [[Kilkenny GAA#Camogie|Kilkenny]] 33 * [[Laois GAA#Camogie|Laois]] 7 * [[Leitrim GAA#Camogie|Leitrim]] 1 * [[Limerick GAA#Camogie|Limerick]] 25 * [[London GAA#Camogie|London]] 7 * [[Longford GAA#Camogie|Longford]] 1 * [[Louth GAA#Camogie|Louth]] 6 * [[Mayo GAA#Camogie|Mayo]] 3 * [[Meath GAA#Camogie|Meath]] 14 * [[Monaghan GAA#Camogie|Monaghan]] 4 * [[New South Wales GAA#Camogie|New South Wales]] 5 * [[North American GAA#Camogie|United States]] 7 * [[Offaly GAA#Camogie|Offaly]] 12 * [[Roscommon GAA#Camogie|Roscommon]] 7 * [[Sligo GAA#Camogie|Sligo]] 2 * [[Tipperary GAA#Camogie|Tipperary]] 32 * [[Tyrone GAA#Camogie|Tyrone]] 10 * [[Waterford GAA#Camogie|Waterford]] 16 * [[Australasia GAA#Camogie|W. Australia]] 1 * [[Westmeath GAA#Camogie|Westmeath]] 13 * [[Wexford GAA#Camogie|Wexford]] 33 * [[Wicklow GAA#Camogie|Wicklow]] 13 * [[Toronto GAA#Camogie|Toronto]] 2 {{Div col end}} ==Competitions== ===All-Ireland Championship=== The county is the unit of structure in elite competition, responsible for organising club competitions within the county unit and for fielding inter-county teams in the various grades of the [[All-Ireland Senior Camogie Championship|All-Ireland championships]] and [[National Camogie League]]. * Eleven counties competed for the elite [[All-Ireland Senior Camogie Championship]] in 2018 for which the [[O'Duffy Cup]] is awarded: [[Clare GAA#Camogie|Clare]], [[Cork GAA#Camogie|Cork]], [[Dublin GAA#Camogie|Dublin]], [[Galway GAA#Camogie|Galway]], [[Kilkenny GAA#Camogie|Kilkenny]], [[Limerick GAA#Camogie|Limerick]], [[Meath GAA#Camogie|Meath]], [[Offaly GAA#Camogie|Offaly]], [[Tipperary GAA#Camogie|Tipperary]], [[Waterford GAA#Camogie|Waterford]], and [[Wexford GAA#Camogie|Wexford]]. The All-Ireland Final is held every year in [[Croke Park]] during September, usually on the week between the [[hurling]] final and [[Gaelic football]] final, and attracts attendances of up to 33,000. The senior camogie championship finals tends to be less eventful than their counterparts in the men's sport of hurling. There are lower score tallies and seldom is there a goal. Only fourteen points were scored by the winning team in the [[2018 All-Ireland Senior Camogie Championship Final|2018 senior final]], and most points in the game followed the awarding of frees. Ten points was sufficient to determine the winner of the [[2017 All-Ireland Senior Camogie Championship Final|2017 senior final]].{{cite news|first=Dermot|last=Crowe|url=https://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-games/camogie/dermot-crowe-breaking-new-ground-on-final-day-as-kilkenny-look-to-bury-pain-of-defeat-38477275.html|title=Breaking new ground on final day as Kilkenny look to bury pain of defeat|work=[[Sunday Independent (Ireland)|Sunday Independent]]|date=8 September 2019|accessdate=8 September 2019|quote=Recent finals have been without goals and scorelines have stayed relatively low compared to hurling. Ten points won the final two years ago. The winning total last year was 14 points. The majority of the scores in last year's final came from frees.}} * The [[All-Ireland Senior Club Camogie Championship|All Ireland Club Championship]] is staged at Senior, Intermediate and Junior level, usually reaching the final stages in November–December or the following March. * Eleven teams will contest the second-tier [[All-Ireland Intermediate Camogie Championship|Jack McGrath Cup]] in 2018 (All Ireland intermediate championship): [[Antrim GAA#Camogie|Antrim]], [[Carlow GAA#Camogie|Carlow]], [[Derry GAA#Camogie|Derry]], [[Down GAA#Camogie|Down]], [[Kildare GAA#Camogie|Kildare]], [[Laois GAA#Camogie|Laois]], and [[Westmeath GAA#Camogie|Westmeath]], and the second teams of [[Cork GAA#Camogie|Cork]], [[Galway GAA#Camogie|Galway]], [[Kilkenny GAA#Camogie|Kilkenny]], and [[Tipperary GAA#Camogie|Tipperary]]. * Seven teams contested the third-tier [[Kay Mills Cup]] (All Ireland junior or 'Premier Junior" championship) in 2018: [[Armagh GAA#Camogie|Armagh]], [[Kerry GAA#Camogie|Kerry]], [[Roscommon GAA#Camogie|Roscommon]], and the second teams of [[Clare GAA#Camogie|Clare]], [[Dublin GAA#Camogie|Dublin]], [[Limerick GAA#Camogie|Limerick]], and [[Offaly GAA#Camogie|Offaly]]. * Six teams contest the fourth-tier [[All-Ireland Junior Camogie Championship#Nancy Murray Cup|Nancy Murray Cup]] (or Junior A championship), [[Carlow GAA#Camogie|Carlow]], [[Cavan GAA#Camogie|Cavan]], [[Monaghan GAA#Camogie|Monaghan]], [[Tyrone GAA#Camogie|Tyrone]], [[Westmeath GAA#Camogie|Westmeath]], and the second team of [[Offaly GAA#Camogie|Offaly]]. * Three teams contest the fifth-tier [[All-Ireland Junior Camogie Championship#Máire Ní Chinnéide Cup|Máire Ní Chinnéide Cup]], (or Junior B championship), [[Wicklow GAA#Camogie|Wicklow]], and the second teams of [[Kildare GAA#Camogie|Kildare]] and [[Meath GAA#Camogie|Meath]]. * [[London GAA#Camogie|London]] competed in the ((National Camogie League)) in The [[National Camogie League 2010|2010]] season although not in [[National Camogie League 2011|2011]]. * Although six counties do not compete at adult level: [[Donegal GAA#Camogie|Donegal]], [[Fermanagh GAA#Camogie|Fermanagh]], [[Leitrim GAA#Camogie|Leitrim]], [[Longford GAA#Camogie|Longford]], [[Mayo GAA#Camogie|Mayo]] and [[Sligo GAA#Camogie|Sligo]] do not compete at adult level, clubs from [[Fermanagh GAA#Camogie|Fermanagh]], [[Kerry GAA#Camogie|Kerry]] and [[Mayo GAA#Camogie|Mayo]] have won honours and [[Donegal GAA#Camogie|Donegal]] have contested divisional finals at under-14 [[Feile na nGael]] level. Both [[Louth GAA#Camogie|Louth]] (in [[All-Ireland Senior Camogie Championship 1934|1934]] and [[All-Ireland Senior Camogie Championship 1936|1936]]) and [[Mayo GAA#Camogie|Mayo]] (in [[All-Ireland Senior Camogie Championship 1959|1959]]) have contested the [[All-Ireland Senior Camogie Championship|All Ireland senior final]] in the past. *There are age-graded All Ireland championships at [[All-Ireland Minor Camogie Championship|Minor A]], [[All-Ireland Minor Camogie Championship#All Ireland Minor B Finals|Minor B]], and [[All-Ireland Minor Camogie Championship#All Ireland Minor C Finals|Minor C]], and [[All-Ireland Minor Camogie Championship#All Ireland Under-16 Camogie Finals|Under-16 A]], [[All-Ireland Minor Camogie Championship#All Ireland Under-16 B Finals|B]] and [[All-Ireland Minor Camogie Championship#All Ireland Under-16 C Finals|C]] level. ===National League=== The [[National Camogie League|National League]] is staged during the winter-spring months, with four divisions of team graded by ability. ===Provincial championships=== Provincial championships take place at all levels, independent of the All Ireland series which has been run on an open draw basis since 1973. ===International and inter-provincial=== Ireland plays a [[Composite rules shinty-hurling|camogie-shinty]] international against [[Shinty|Scotland]] each year. The [[Gael Linn Cup]] is an inter-provincial competition played at senior and junior level. The sport is closely associated with the [[Celtic Congress]]. Two former [[Camogie Association]] presidents [[Máire Ní Chinnéide]] and [[Agnes O'Farrelly]] were also presidents of [[Celtic Congress]] and exhibition matches have been held at the Celtic Congress since 1938. The first such exhibition match, on the [[Isle of Man]] in 1938, marked the first appearance of [[Kathleen Cody (athlete)|Kathleen Cody]], who became one of the stars of the 1940s. ===Inter-collegiate=== The [[Ashbourne Cup|Ashbourne]] and Purcell Cups and Father Meachair seven-a-side are the principal inter-collegiate competitions. ===Schools=== There is also a programme of [[All Ireland Colleges Camogie Championship|provincial and All Ireland championships at secondary schools senior and junior levels]], differentiated by the years of secondary school cycle, with years 4–6 competing in the senior competition, and years 1–3 competing at junior level. [[Cumann na mBunscoil]] organises competitions at primary school level. ===Féile na nGael=== Camogie competitions for club teams featuring under-14 players are played in four divisions as part of the annual [[Féile na nGael]] festival. The county that is selected for a particular year, all their clubs host teams from all around the country representing their county. Host clubs get families to take in two or three children for a couple of days. ==Records== Cork have won the most Camogie All-Ireland titles with 27, the last being in 2017. See [[All-Ireland Senior Camogie Championship]]. [[Cork GAA#Camogie|Cork]] have won the most [[National Camogie League]] titles with 16. See [[National Camogie League]] Wexford having won three in a row from 2010 to 2012 ==Awards== [[Camogie All Stars Awards]] are awarded annually to the elite players who have performed best in each of the 15 positions on a traditional camogie team. Player of the year and other achievement awards have also been awarded to leading players for several decades. ===Team of the Century=== Picked in 2004{{cite web|url=http://www.camogie.ie/AboutCamogie/TeamoftheCentury/tabid/103/Default.aspx|title=Team of the century |website=Camogie.ie|accessdate=15 January 2018}} #[[Eileen Duffy|Eileen Duffy-O'Mahony]] ([[Dublin GAA#Camogie|Dublin]]) #[[Liz Neary]] ([[Kilkenny GAA#Camogie|Kilkenny]]) #[[Marie Costine|Marie Costine-O'Donovan]] ([[Cork GAA#Camogie|Cork]]) #[[Mary Sinnott|Mary Sinnott-Dinan]] ([[Wexford GAA#Camogie|Wexford]]) #[[Bridie McGarry|Bridie Martin-McGarry]] ([[Kilkenny GAA#Camogie|Kilkenny]]) #[[Sandie Fitzgibbon]] ([[Cork GAA#Camogie|Cork]]) #[[Margaret O'Leary|Margaret O'Leary-Leacy]] ([[Wexford GAA#Camogie|Wexford]]) #[[Mairéad McAtamney|Mairéad McAtamney-Magill]] ([[Antrim GAA#Camogie|Antrim]]) # [[Linda Mellerick]] ([[Cork GAA#Camogie|Cork]]) # [[Sophie Brack]] ([[Dublin GAA#Camogie|Dublin]]) #[[Kathleen Mills|Kathleen Mills-Hill]] ([[Dublin GAA#Camogie|Dublin]]) #[[Joni Traynor]] ([[London GAA#Camogie|Kilkenny]]) #[[Úna O'Connor]] ([[Dublin GAA#Camogie|Dublin]]) #[[Pat Moloney|Pat Moloney-Lenihan]] ([[Cork GAA#Camogie|Cork]]) #[[Deirdre Hughes]] ([[Tipperary GAA#Camogie|Tipperary]]) #[[Angela Downey|Angela Downey-Browne]] ([[Kilkenny GAA#Camogie|Kilkenny]]) ==Literary references== A reference to camogie features in one of Lucky's speeches in ''[[Waiting for Godot]]'' by Irish playwright [[Samuel Beckett]]. ==See also== * [[Women's shinty]] * [[Camogie All Stars Awards]] * [[Ashbourne Cup]] * [[Poc Fada]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Wiktionary|camogie}} * [http://www.camogie.ie Camogie.ie] Official Camogie Association Website {{Gaelic games}} {{Ladies' Gaelic games}} {{Gaelic Athletic Association}} {{Team sports}} {{Women's sports}} [[Category:Camogie| ]] [[Category:Gaelic games]] [[Category:Sports originating in Ireland]] [[Category:Team sports]]
